raw_text:
Guantanamo man 'suing government'
 
 A British terror suspect held in Guantanamo Bay for 33 months plans to sue the government, it is reported.
 
 Martin Mubanga claimed in the Observer that an MI6 officer played a key role in consigning him to the US camp in Cuba, following his arrest in Zambia. Mr Mubanga, 32, from Wembley, London, said he was brutally interrogated and daubed with urine at the camp. The home secretary said he would not be launching an investigation and that the media reports were not "well informed". Mr Mubanga, who has dual British and Zambian nationality, was one of four Britons who were released from the US camp in January.
 
 He said he was sent there after being interrogated by a British man who said he was from MI6, shortly after his arrest in Zambia in March 2002. Mr Mubanga said he had been in Afghanistan and Pakistan to study Islam. But he said he was unable to return to the UK because he had lost his British passport, and was travelling on his Zambian passport instead. Mr Mubanga said the "MI6 agent" told him the passport had been found in a cave in Afghanistan along with documents listing Jewish groups in New York and suggested he had been on an al-Qaeda reconnaissance mission. Mr Mubanga said the man, and an American female defence official, tried to recruit him as an agent, but he refused and within three weeks was told he would be sent to Guantanamo Bay.
 
 His lawyer Louise Christian said: "'We are hoping to issue proceedings for the misfeasance of officials who colluded with the Americans in effectively kidnapping him and taking him to Guantanamo." And Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrats' foreign affairs spokesman, said it was vital to establish whether ministers approved Mr Mubanga's transfer to Guantanamo. But a Foreign Office spokesman said he could not comment on the activities of British intelligence or security agencies. And Home Secretary Charles Clarke told BBC One's Breakfast with Frost: "I'm not organising a specific investigation into it." Mr Mubanga is the first of the four detainees freed last month to give a media interview. He told the Observer his worst moment was when he was told he would be released last March, only to be confined and told he would be there for many more years.
 
 He claimed he was stripped of his clothes and mattress and forced to remain in an empty metal box, naked except for boxer shorts. And he said an interrogator used a mop to daub him with his own urine while he was chained hand and foot. Mr Mubanga, who insists he does not feel bitter, said: "I've lost three years of my life, because I was a Muslim. He added: "The authorities wanted to break me but they strengthened me. They've made me what I am - even if I'm not quite sure yet who that person is." The US government denied the claims, saying it condemned and prohibited torture. In a statement, it said: "The Department of Defense has no doubt that Mr Mubanga was properly detained as an enemy combatant under the laws of war. "He was detained to prevent him from fighting against the US and our allies in the war on terror." But Fair Trials Abroad director Stephen Jakobi said there were similarities between Mr Mubanga's account and those of other Guantanamo detainees. He said: "The pattern is the same. The real problem is the concentration camp conditions in Guantanamo. "Is [Charles Clarke] really pretending this is all made up?" Mr Mubanga and the three other freed British detainees were released without charge by UK police on their return from Cuba.
llama3.2:1b: Martin Mubanga, a 32-year-old Briton held at Guantanamo Bay for over 3 years, plans to sue the US government after being subjected to brutal interrogations and torture in Cuba.
He claimed MI6 agents played a key role in his capture, including convincing him he was from MI6 and making false claims about his mission.
llama3.2:3b: A 32-year-old British terror suspect held at Guantanamo Bay for 33 months plans to sue the government, alleging he was brutally interrogated and subjected to torture.
He claims an MI6 officer played a key role in his detention and that he was daubed with urine while chained hand and foot.
The Home Secretary denies any investigation will be launched, saying reports are "not well informed".
gemma2:2b: Martin Mubanga, a British terror suspect, is suing the government for alleged illegal detention at Guantanamo Bay for 33 months after his arrest in Zambia.
He claims he was sent there by an MI6 officer who falsely accused him of terrorism and attempted to recruit him into espionage.
Mubanga also claims he suffered abuse and torture during his time at Guantanamo, including being stripped naked, doused with urine, and kept in a metal box for days.
The US government denies his claims, stating he was detained as an enemy combatant.
Fair Trials Abroad director Stephen Jakobi suggests the pattern of claims from other Guantanamo detainees indicates a larger problem with the camp's conditions.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A British man accused of being an enemy combatant in America has sued the US government, saying he was tortured during his 33-month detention at Guantanamo Bay.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A British terror suspect, Martin Mubanga, held for 33 months at Guantanamo Bay due to his arrest in Zambia, plans to sue the government after claims he was brutally interrogated and daubed with urine during captivity.
The Home Secretary dismissed reports as not "well informed" despite acknowledging Mubanga's allegations.
He is Britain's first detainee released from the US camp since January 2015.
qwen2.5:3b: A British terror suspect held at Guantanamo Bay for 33 months, Martin Mubanga, plans to sue the government over his detention.
Claiming an MI6 officer conspired in his imprisonment following his arrest in Zambia, he alleges brutal interrogations and recruitment attempts.
Now released with three other Britons, Mubanga describes harsh conditions and torture at Guantanamo.
His lawyer hopes to bring proceedings for officials' misconduct.
The US government denies claims of abuse while the UK home secretary states no investigation will be organized.
While similarities exist between Mubanga's account and those of other detainees, his release is without charge by UK police upon their return from Cuba.
opencoder:1.5b:
As an AI, I don't have feelings or personal experiences, but I can provide a concise summary of your provided text:

A British terror suspect in Guantanamo Bay for 33 months plans to sue the government.
Martin Mubanga's account is reported in the Observer, which claims he played a key role in consigning him to the US camp in Cuba.
He was brutally interrogated and daubed with urine at the camp.
The home secretary said he would not launch an investigation and that the media reports were not "well informed."
He told the Observer his worst moment was when he was released last March, only to be confined and told he would be there for many more years.
He claims he stripped of clothes and mattress, chained hands, and felt no bitterness.
The US government denied the claims, saying it condemns and prohibits torture.
It said: "The Department of Defense has no doubt that Mr Mubanga was properly detained as an enemy combatant under the laws of war."
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Martin Mubanga, a British terror suspect, was released from Guantanamo Bay after 33 months for alleged coercion under torture.
An MI6 officer from Zambia consigned him there following his arrest in 2002, leading him to an US camp in Cuba.
He claims to have been trapped after being interrogated by British men, later described as a "MI6 agent."
Mubanga, from London, had studied Islam before traveling to Afghanistan and Pakistan but was detained due to losing his British passport while travelling on Zambian one.
He was released without charge, though details of his detention remain unclear, especially the implications for him.
tinyllama:1.1b: A British terror suspect, Martin Muabanaga, has sued the government for allegedly harming him during his time in Guantañamo Bay, which he claims was used to harshly interrogate and torture him, without a fair trial or due process.
The home secretary, Charles Clark, denied the accusations, but Fair Trials Abrona director Stephen Jakobi criticized the government's treatment of other detained individuals in Guantañamo Bay.
The case is the first time a freeed British detainee has given media interviews.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The summary conveys the following information: 
1.
A British man, Martin Mubanga, who was detained at Guantanamo Bay for three years and is now suing the government for alleged misconduct during his imprisonment.
He claims that he was brutally interrogated by an MI6 officer who played a key role in his confinement.
The Home Office, which is the UK's civilian organization responsible for dealing with public affairs, said it would not be launching any investigation into the allegations made by Mr. Mubanga.
He claims that he was strip-searched and subjected to urine-soaked blankets at Guantanamo Bay.
The Observer reported on Martin's account of his experiences, which were not discredited by MI6.
This case highlights the concentration camp conditions at Guantanamo, where many detainees have been held for more than three years.
phi:2.7b: A British terror suspect held in Guantanamo Bay for 33 months plans to sue the government, claiming he was kidnapped and sent there by a British intelligence agent.
The man says he was brutally interrogated and subjected to torture at the camp.
He is one of four Britons who were released from Guantanamo last month, but refuses to return to the UK due to losing his passport.
orca-mini:3b: A British man held in Guantanamo Bay for 33 months plans to sue the government, claiming he was interrogated by a British man who said he was from MI6 and forced to remain in an empty metal box with only a mop to daub him with urine.
hermes3:3b: British Guantanamo detainee plans to sue government over alleged MI6 role in his capture and interrogation.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A man held in Guantanamo Bay for 33 months, Martin Mubanga, plans to sue the UK government over alleged involvement of an MI6 officer in his detention.
Mubanga claims that an MI6 agent falsely accused him of having links with al-Qaeda and played a role in sending him to Guantanamo Bay.
The home secretary has stated that there will be no investigation into this matter.
chatgpt-4o-latest: British terror suspect Martin Mubanga, held in Guantanamo Bay for 33 months, plans to sue the government, alleging that an MI6 officer played a key role in his detention after his arrest in Zambia.
Mubanga claims he was brutally interrogated, mistreated, and falsely accused of being on an al-Qaeda mission.
He says he was pressured to become an informant but refused and was subsequently sent to Guantanamo.
His lawyer argues that British officials colluded in his detention, while politicians call for clarity on the government's role.
The UK government denies wrongdoing and refuses to investigate.
Mubanga, released without charge, describes harsh treatment but insists he is not bitter.
The US government maintains he was lawfully detained as an enemy combatant, while human rights advocates highlight systemic abuses at Guantanamo.
stablelm2:1.6b: A British terror suspect, Martin Mubanga, plans to sue the government after being held in Guantanamo Bay for several months.
He claims an MI6 officer played a key role in his detention following his arrest in Zambia.
Mubanga was interrogated and subjected to cruel treatment at the US camp.
His lawyer is hoping to issue proceedings for misfeasance of officials who collaborated with American authorities to kidnap him.
Mubanga's account echoes those of other Guantanamo detainees, raising concerns about concentration camp conditions.
The US government denies the claims of torture but acknowledges proper detention as an enemy combatant under the laws  of war.
Mubanga and three other British detainees were released without charge by UK police on their return from Cuba.
granite3.1-dense:2b: British terror suspect Martin Mubanga, held at Guantanamo Bay for 33 months, intends to sue the government over his treatment.
Mubanga, a 32-year-old dual British and Zambian national from Wembley, claims an MI6 officer facilitated his detention in Cuba following his arrest in Zambia in March 2002.
He alleges brutal interrogation, being stripped naked, and having urine daubed on him with a mop by US interrogators.
The Home Secretary dismissed media reports as "not well-informed," but Mubanga's lawyer plans to file misfeasance claims against officials who collaborated in his "kidnapping."
Mubanga, one of four British detainees released in January 2004, said the experience left him more resolute as a Muslim.
The US government denied the allegations, stating Mubanga was detained as an enemy combatant to prevent potential harm during the war on terror.
Fair Trials Abroad director noted similarities between Mubanga's account and those of other Guantanamo detainees, emphasizing the grave conditions in the camp.
All four freed British detainees were released without charge upon returning to the UK.
